content: Agreeing with the things Ian Millhiser would change, I have a longer list containing other items that are perhaps even more important: Require elections to support some sort of “ranked-choice”, “instant run-off” voting — c.f. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ranked_voting_system https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instant-runoff_voting https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Condorcet_method This type of innovation is essential to allow 3rd party candidates to continue campaigning throughout the electoral season and avoid discussions of “vote wasting”, etc. This would make elections much more about issues and who is best on merit and less about fear of the worser evil.Campaign finance reform — including legislative overturn of “Citizens United”End the practice of rewriting public legislation at the last minute. End most closed-door exec sessions of Congress and Committees.Provide more avenues for the public to directly argue issues in Congress. Groups of citizens including experts should not be lesser voices compared to K-street lobbyists. In a better system, the different arguments and facts would be made publicly available and open to public criticism/debate prior to Congressional voting.The US Security State now takes up more than 60% of the annual discretionary budget — that figure is too large to begin with, it is absurd that the Pentagon has not been audited in 2 decades, and it is absurd that so much of this activity is kept secret from the public while whistleblowers in the public interest are thrown in jail for their efforts.
